body.p: As suggested by you I have obtained the rest of signatures of the Jurymen who tried Hauserman; and your pardon of him will therefore be by the Jury which that convicted him. I have not seen the Commonwealth's attorney & cannot see him as he is out of the county and will be gone for a long time so far as I can I do not think, however that you will require other support in a Mercifully that of the Jury.

I trust, my Dear Govenor that you will send Houserman home at an early day. Rest assured that you will do right -- this pardon It is but political, for aught that I know Hauserman may be the vilest abolitionist in the land. I know nothing of his political cause and don't care. I think him wrongly in prison & I want him out for the cause of right and for nothing else.
I am sorey not to have again seen you while you were here. A sick child however kept him at home. I hope to see you again soon.
Dear , My Dear Govenor in appoint me a Notary Public. I name my Commission by Tuesday Morning next if it can possibly be had, as some has been put off for me to do that day.
